headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: Deep Dive, the Shark Wars. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: For great white sharks you do not want to be outside of a cage with one of those animals because, you know, if they sneeze, something really bad can happen. Fortunately here we were under the watchful eye of some of the most experienced shark folks in the world. So we were fortunate to do it.

utterances.speaker: ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Boris Sanchez, can't wait to watch it. Thanks so much for coming on to promo it for us.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much, Alisyn.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The all-new episode of "THE WHOLE STORY WITH ANDERSON COOPER" air next, right here on CNN.Thank you so much for joining me this evening. I'm Alisyn Camerota. Have a wonderful Sunday night and upcoming week.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.Sharks have been around for at least 400 million years, even before dinosaurs walked the earth. These apex predators have reputation for attacking all sorts of marine life, which sometimes includes the occasional human. But are sharks a danger to people or are people a danger to sharks? According to scientists, more than one-third of shark species are at risk of extinction, mostly due to overfishing. Some fishermen in the U.S. argue that sharks are coming out in greater numbers than ever stealing their catch and making it harder for them to earn a living. CNN's Boris Sanchez is an experienced diver, and over the next hour he takes us under water with sharks to show us both the beauty and danger of these creatures. We want to warn you some of the images you'll see in this hour may be disturbing. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN ANCHOR (voice-over): Below the surface at Tiger Beach, you're supposed to steady your breath, limit your movement, and keep your head on a swivel. There are shadows lurking, ancient predators with remorseless eyes, and staggered rows of razor-sharp teeth, circling closer. Jagged silhouettes that hold a lethal reputation. A beast that inspires dread and awe. KARYL BREWSTER-GEISZ, NOAA FISHERIES RULEMAKING BRANCH CHIEF: They are such fascinating, iconic creatures. DR. BORIS WORM, MARINE BIOLOGIST: It's like a cross between a dinosaur, a tiger, and a puppy dog.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They eat everything. They're eating machines. Yes, they're dangerous. If you go into the water, you got a good chance of getting bit.

utterances.speaker: CRISTINA ZENATO, PROFESSIONAL DIVER, SHARK JUNCTION
utterances.sentences: How about the word vulnerable? How many people would also say the word shark with vulnerable?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Sharks are now at the center of a deepening conflict.ROBERT "FLY" NAVARRO, RECREATIONAL FISHERMAN: There's just a lot more sharks out there. So there's a lot more interactions. My question is, is this the new normal?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Between those competing with apex predators, anglers struggling to make a living off the ocean.

utterances.speaker: BOB ZALES II, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, SOUTHEASTERN FISHERIES ASSOCIATION
utterances.sentences: You go out there and about half of your catch is eaten by sharks.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And those who know these creatures by name and personality.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: I can say Grandma was comfortable with me. I can say Grandma allow me to have her in my lap and pat her literally.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Advocates who say a negative reputation is unwarranted are worried that current global trends signal a bleak future.

utterances.speaker: JILLIAN MORRIS, SHARK CONSERVATIONIST
utterances.sentences: They're not these mindless eating machines. There's so much to learn about them, and they're so misunderstood.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: The movie "Jaws" famously portrayed sharks as a huge threat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You're going to need a bigger boat.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: It was so successful that it caused a whole genre of movies to be produced. That's how they perpetuated that message.

utterances.speaker: ALEX CARRIER, SHARK EXPERT
utterances.sentences: People think of shark and they think of violent stuff, gore, blood, teeth.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: And nothing could be further from the truth.DR. NEIL HAMMERSCHLAG, MARINE ECOLOGIST: They aren't mindless killers, but in fact these amazing, curious, and just graceful animals.

utterances.speaker: FREDRICKA WHITFIELD, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Three victims injured in separate shark attacks.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: While shark attacks do happen, experts say they're rare.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: Sharks can be a risk to human beings. But we have less than 10 fatalities a year worldwide.We're here in Herring Cove, Nova Scotia. We are tracking some of the white sharks in the region.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Boris Worm is a marine biologist in Nova Scotia, studying shark populations.What got you interested in sharks?

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: Sharks are older than trees. Sharks as a group are older than the rings around Saturn.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Marine ecologist Neil Hammerschlag operates shark expeditions in the North Atlantic.

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: We know that predators in general help maintain balance and regulate ecosystems. When they are removed, there can be this trickling effect throughout the ecosystem. If I have a fancy watch, right, and I open it up and I pull out a random spring, I'm not exactly sure what's going to happen, but probably the watch is not going to function as well.A lot of people like to think about shark's role in the ecosystem, they're eating all these fish and helping control populations that way. Well, they certainly have to eat. But one of the big ways that sharks have helped balance the ecosystem is by scaring fish. And that's important because it prevents any one species from like taking over and out-competing the other ones which promotes diversity.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: Sharks often they live young like us. They mature late like us. They have few offspring throughout their life like humans. Human couldn't be fished sustainably over time. Sharks can't either.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What do humans use sharks for?

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: Shark meat for a long time was not prized at all. Sharks were often caught accidentally. Then in the 1990s, with increasing affluence in Asia, particularly in China and neighboring countries, shark fins became a highly priced delicacy.

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: It was seen as a cultural sign of wealth having shark fin soup. Certain fins are more valuable. They could go from $50 to $500 a pound. And what would happen is the sharks would be brought towards the boat. It's something called finning. The fins would be cut off, and the rest of the shark would be thrown away at sea to die. Essentially, these sharks suffocate to death. Mutilated sharks caused an outcry.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: And that contributed very much to the heightened extinction risk we now see for sharks. Since then that practice of cutting off the shark fins and selling them for profit has been banned in many countries. Now fishers are incentivized to land the whole shark.

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: What has happened is that it seems to have created a bit of a demand for shark meat.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: And also a very rapidly increasing trade in shark liver oil. A very valuable oil called squalene, which is used, for example, in supplements or in cosmetics.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Despite an increased global demand for shark meat, the FDA warns that it could contain high levels of mercury.

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: Shark meat is not good for your health. So my own studies have found that sharks' tissues have very high levels of toxins like mercury, arsenic, and even in neurological toxins linked to development of Alzheimer's disease in humans.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You did research about shark finning regulations and whether that helped to reduce mortality. What did you find?

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: We were really interested in finding out whether the rise of shark finning regulations around the world has helped to reduce mortality of sharks. And the short answer is no. It did not because it simply incentivized fishers to land the whole shark, use the whole shark, creating additional markets for their products. In some sense raising the value of the shark.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Worm's research also looks at the countries where the most sharks are killed. While Indonesia regulates shark fishing it tops the list with illegal shark exports.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: You see the big six, six countries make up 50 percent of global shark mortality. As you see, the United States at number eight, with an estimated 2.8 million sharks killed according to our data. It's a major shark fishing nations, but they're also doing things for sustainability but I think most people would be surprised to learn that there's so many sharks being fished in the states.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: How serious is the overfishing of sharks as a problem around the world?

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: The loss of sharks from directed fishing from sharks and also sharks being caught unintentionally is a major, a major problem. This is like a global phenomenon.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Despite warnings that sharks are in danger globally, some anglers say the shark population in the United States is out of control.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And a recreational fisherman says the humanizing of sharks has gone too far.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: I could show you pages and pages of Instagram accounts on personal sharks that people are feeding off the coast of Florida. They have names.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is Snooty, a female lemon shark.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: I do not see kids going to farms and naming chickens and naming cows.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Next, we traveled to the Bahamas to meet those naming sharks and we get up close to some of the creatures they're trying to save.Do you think the shark knows you're trying to help it?

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. Otherwise why would she keep coming back when it hurts? Because trying to remove a hook hurts, but she'll do a tight circle and come back in.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) SANCHEZ (voice-over): For those who cherish shark interactions, few places on earth rival the Bahamas.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: Sharks are living, breathing, thinking, feeling, sentient beings, which are necessary in our world.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And at Shark Junction, a dive site just offshore from Grand Bahamas Island, Cristina Zenato feels at home.What is it like when you are under the water with sharks?

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: To me it's like being home. It's as peaceful as sitting on my couch, petting my dogs. I'm happy. I'm relaxed. I enjoy their presence. So for me it's an animal that is easy to understand. It's not conniving. It is not backstabbing. I deal easier with sharks sometimes than I deal with people.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You've never felt fear in the water with sharks.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: I never felt fear. No. I grew up with the notion, it's a very beautiful sentence that my dad always told me. There are no monsters in the sea, only the ones you make up in your head.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You were instrumental in changing the way that sharks are treated here in the Bahamas.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: I started a petition in 2009 that gathered at the time 25,000 signatures online.SANCHEZ (voice-over): A petition that helped establish a marine sanctuary for sharks across the Bahamas' 700 islands.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: You cannot fish, you cannot kill, you cannot even land a dead shark.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: We actually recognize each and every one of them. I have hand signals with their names and I can point them out to you and they have personalities as well.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Personalities we'll greet once we sued up.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: All right. So change suit and we're going to use this one here. Then slide it over your hips. Kind of like a knight in shining armor. And they're designed to prevent abrasions and cuts. Legs start forward, ready, go. Look out. So as we go down we reached the bottom of the land it's 30 feet, and then we'll move right in the middle of the sand.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And as we settle into position, Zenato spots familiar faces.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: But we have hook. We have Half-Baked. We have Vulkan. We have Crook. We have Floppy. Reach out and pet the shark head. Same as if you would be shaking somebody's hand. Relax, right? Gentle breathing. Don't trying to do too much. A way for the shark to come in. You're going to reach out and pet.I had a shark I call Grandma. I've known it for 14 years. And now she's just gone. Grandma accepted me. I can say Grandma was comfortable with me. I can say Grandma allowed me to have her in my lap and pet her literally. And it's every time the same feeling. It's a magical moment for, you know, eight and a half, nine for wild animal to say in this moment, I trust you and I will sit here with you. So I always worry, what if they go into the Florida waters when they're not protected? What if somebody comes here a night and nobody is watching and does something to them? So it's a mix of laugh and worry when I'm with them.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Zenato also aims to heal those wounded by fishing hooks.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: So when a shark shows up with a hook, I tried to see where the hook is lodged. If the shark is willing but maybe stop the shark tried to grab the hook.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Do you think the shark knows you're trying to help it? ZENATOhurts? Because trying to remove a hook hurts but she'll do a tight circle and come back in. SANCHEZ (voice-over): In 30 years of removing more than 350 hooks Zenato says she's never been bitten by a shark.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: They can be sometimes demanding, but the satisfaction of being able to relieve a shark of that presence is enormous.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Oh, man, that was incredible. That was unreal.

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: It was really good. Very nice.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Tomorrow we're headed to Tiger Beach to do some free diving. Do you have any advice?

utterances.speaker: ZENATO
utterances.sentences: Wear two eyes on the back of your head.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Is that the Cayman Jason?JASON WASHINGTON, AWARD-WINNING PHOTOGRAPHER: Mr. Sanchez.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What's going on?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: Welcome aboard, my friend.SANCHEZ (voice-over): More than two hours off the coast of Grand Bahama, Tiger Beach is world renowned for its strike namesake. Unlike reef sharks, we will not be petting tiger sharks. Among the largest of the species they can weigh nearly a ton and they grow up to 18 feet in length. They're perfect models for conservation as Jason Washington, an award-winning photographer, acclaimed for his work with free divers.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Why free dive Tiger Beach?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: It gives us an opportunity to get a little bit closer to the animals. But the shark is going to be moving all around us while we're down there. So it'll give us an opportunity to swim alongside with these creatures.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What does your ability to photograph them and shine a different light on them mean for conservation?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: When you want to turn the world on to the plight of these animals, you want to get in the water with the big ones and show the viewing audience that they're not mindless killers. You know, they play a critical role in our world's oceans and they deserve our protection. And I do that specifically through photography.

utterances.speaker: FORBES
utterances.sentences: Out here we have two rules. Basically do not touch the shark. Don't let the shark touch you, all right? You see me going four, five, six, that number indicates how many tiger sharks are in the area. These tiger sharks are nice, beautiful, majestic creatures. But let's not give the tiger shark the opportunity to get too close to us. We have our second bait box down there. That's going to be the main bait box we are feeding from.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So you saw a familiar face down there?

utterances.speaker: FORBES
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's tiger shark. They've been frequent in Tiger Beach for about five or six years. She's quite famous actually. Her name is Butt Face which means (INAUDIBLE) her face is indented. She's actually one of the most sneaky sharks. Most tiger sharks come around. They come nice and low and stay at the bait box.  She basically does what she wants to do.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Butt Face plays by her own rules.

utterances.speaker: FORBES
utterances.sentences: Pretty much. Pretty much.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: As free divers, what we want to do is get our heart rate low. We want to get our CO2 levels low. And we get our oxygen levels high. So we do that for our breather process. All right. Ready for this?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Let's do it.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: What we're looking for immediately as we enter the water are these lemons and these reef sharks that are circling behind the boat. And we're going to make our way back down toward the end of this tagline. And that's where we'll be free-diving from.Now these sharks on the bottom are going to be coming into the bait station. They're going to make a big circle and they're going to come into the bait station to get their hand out of food, their treat. And then when we feel like we're in a safe position we're going to dive down and swim with these animals. So I'm going to be taking pictures of you with the tiger sharks in the background. Make sure you're looking all around above, below, all the sides. Because these sharks can come from different angles.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: The amount of energy that is spent getting down there, getting close to the shark, keeping up with it, and also keeping your head on a swivel because there were several moments where you're focused on one and a couple of them are behind you or in your peripheral. So it requires a lot of energy to not only be close to the shark and moving with it, but also to be alert. WASHINGTONbeneath the water, the world suddenly becomes more silent. All the things in my mind are pushed to the periphery and I'm focused 1,000 percent on these sharks. It is the most present that I will ever be.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Watching the feeder is almost like watching a bullfighter. The way that they sort of navigate the space and they navigate the animal's intent and interest because they are very interested in what's happening in that bait box and sort of keeping it at bay and managing it and dancing with it in that moment from an up-close view, there is nothing like that in the world.So we've got a chance to swim with them, right? Now we're going to throw on some scuba gear and get face-to-face. Let's go.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You're clear, go.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Getting that close to a tiger shark and making eye contact with this miracle of Mother Nature, this massive dinosaur, knowing that it is fully capable of ending your existence and then watching as it examines you, sizes you up, and then shares the ocean with you and moves to the side. That to me is profound. It's just awe-inspiring. They come fairly close to you, you could just reach out and touch them. They don't really even care that you're there.I think Butt Face has a bad reputation because she was nothing but pleasant to me personally.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: I'm literally capturing everything that's happening around me. I'm framing the image and then try to line everything up in a composition that's pleasing to my brain. It's a difficult process and it's one of those things that just keeps you coming back for more. And the more you do it, the more addictive it becomes because that's suddenly where you understand that this world is a lot bigger.SANCHEZ (voice-over): When we return controversy over shark fishing tournaments.

utterances.speaker: CARRIER
utterances.sentences: It was just gruesome.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And allegations of animal cruelty when frustrations boil over.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And later --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Reel, reel, reel, reel, reel.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Local anglers are hosting a shark hunting competition.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: To reduce the number of bull sharks in these waters, the event bringing up protesters.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Online petition to stop that event and more than 140,000 signatures.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: The controversial event giving away cash prizes for those who catch the biggest sharks. Fishermen exasperated by costly shark interactions posting to social media that they plan to kill as many as possible. Threatening to butcher them with propellers. And hinting about hiding carcasses.

utterances.speaker: CARRIER
utterances.sentences: Just violent, angry, upset, mob mentality. They came in here. They culled a bunch of bull sharks and the results were immediately felt and seen.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Local dive boat captain Alex Carrier brought claims of animal cruelty to light.There were reports during the tournament of people beheading sharks, of people finning sharks, of people unloading firearms into sharks. How did that make you feel?

utterances.speaker: CARRIER
utterances.sentences: There was a lot of things that were being done illegally. A lot of kill methods that were not allowed being used. There was a lot of disrespect to those sharks once they were caught. Using the sharks as a punching bag. There was a lot of insight video captured from that tournament. It was just gruesome.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What was the ripple effect after the tournament?

utterances.speaker: CARRIER
utterances.sentences: When you kill a certain number of sharks like that, it pushes all the other sharks out and a lot of fishermen kept killing sharks after the tournament. So there's a whole saying, do your part, kill a shark.I made a video that went viral on the tournament. Quickly after I posted that video, I had a couple of people show up at my house wanting to get violent. It was a pretty scary time because I was getting, you know, death threats.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: There's a lot of fishermen out there right now that are very frustrated with sharks. So they have a negative connotation because they keep interacting in a bad way with the fisher.SANCHEZ (voice-over): The tournament's organizer, Robert "Fly" Navarro, says he also became a target.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: I was averaging between two to three death threats a night.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What were people saying?

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: I'm going to shoot you just like people shoot sharks.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You've heard the reports I'm sure of people misbehaving.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: I heard reports of people misbehaving. I never saw anybody misbehaving.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Folks doing inhumane things to the sharks.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: That wasn't the intended purpose. We had a university that was doing samples on all the sharks. I know we harvested nine sharks and we released somewhere like 287 sharks. All I know is we had a 97 percent release rate, which all that stuff went back to NOAA.SANCHEZ (voice-over): But the number of sharks released was thrown into question when hidden camera video that was shot for a documentary circulated on social media. It captures audio of a tournament official instructing fishermen to take the fins and take the meat before dumping dead bodies in the ocean. Navarro, who was at the meeting, later admits more sharks could have been killed than those they harvested. Inside video also captures a fisherman bragging about dragging a shark behind a boat for hours. A state crime in Florida.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: These things are not made to die. We drug this fish for two hours.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Is it possible that there were folks that did things that you wouldn't sanction?

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: 100 percent. I cannot -- I don't know what everybody is doing out there.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You're opposed to shark culls.

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: Oh, since early '70s. When "Jaws" came out, the movie, I was sharp fishing then, but it then -- it's made my business skyrocket, you know, because people wanted to catch a shark.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Customers hire him to take them shark fishing. How many sharks do you think you've caught over the years?

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: About 100,000 sharks. Yes. 50 years don't forget. It's a long time.I mean, if you're out here every day like we are, we're out here 450 times a year, we see what's going on. There's a lot of fish that are on. We protect a list that should be off the protected list. Sandbar. We're going to measure her up, tag her and let her go. There's plenty of sandbar sharks around. I mean, you could catch them just about every day of the week. But why are they on their protected list? I don't know. They shouldn't be. They should be taken off. Come on, I get a picture quick. OK. Open that door. And let her go. We tag probably a couple of hundred sharks a year for NOAA, National Marine Fisheries. They love us all. Hurry up, you need to hurry up. Just keep it tight, keep it going, keep it going. Keep it going. A little bit of time. There you go. That's a bigger fish you got there.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So what's the procedure now? What's the protocol with the great hammerhead?

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: We're going to kill it.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Hammerheads are protected in Florida waters but legal to catch in federal waters three miles offshore.

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: Ten feet at least.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We're tight. Here she comes, coach.

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: A lot of blood. Yes. Get him on, get him on, get him on. Get him on. Big male. Wow, bro. They gone bleeding, he's bleeding all over the place.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: But there's no part of you that feels bad about that shark having a diminished population? And you taking one out of the water?

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: In my opinion, there's no diminishing of a population of hammerheads. They're everywhere. We catch it all the time. If they're so endangered, why did we catch him every day? Just think about that. Honestly.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What would you say to folks who think that you're doing harm to shark populations?

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: One guy doing shark populations harm? I don't know. How does that work? I mean, I'm getting way too much credit.Hang this neuter.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: How many times have you gone out fishing with Mark?

utterances.speaker: DOMINIC CARINI, CUSTOMER
utterances.sentences: Thirty, 30 plus. Maybe 40 times.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What is it about sharks that attracts you to this kind of fishing?

utterances.speaker: CARINI
utterances.sentences: I find it similar probably to like anybody that, you know, wants a big game. As long as it's positive, legal, in the right waters I think big game hunting, a lot of people all over America enjoy it.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Should we stop for a moment, just look over there.(Voice-over): Soon after docking law enforcement approaches the boat.

utterances.speaker: CARINI
utterances.sentences: They're so mean to Mark. Can I put that on film? Everyone is so mean to Mark. Mark is a good person.

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: Someone always calls the police on us. The police officer know that we don't do anything illegal. We're totally 100 percent by the book.

utterances.speaker: CARINI
utterances.sentences: Right here. Look at me, guys.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Despite warnings from the FDA that shark meat could have high levels of mercury, meat from this scalloped hammerhead will soon be delivered to a local homeless shelter, which Mark says he does with every catch.

utterances.speaker: QUARTIANO
utterances.sentences: Good job, Boris.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Coming up, we head to West Palm Beach to explore anglers' frustration and see why they say the U.S. government is leaving them high and dry.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Guess what, you just got sharked.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: You didn't know you were doing a workout today, did you?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: No. No idea.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: And we got a rainbow runner.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: How long have you been doing this?

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Professionally, I've been doing it 33 years.Good luck, buddy. It's become a little bit of an issue, number one, with a lot of boats. Number two, the shark problem. SANCHEZ (voice-over): Robert "Fly" Navarro says that competing against predators on the open water is natural. But the rate at which sharks are feasting on his catch is crippling both the commercial and recreational fishing industry.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: It's every fish you're fighting.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Navarro says sharks are eating what he catches before he can reel it into the boat at an alarming rate. He says the phenomenon known as depredation is happening more often than he's ever seen.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Lean back. And then wind out, there you go. Somebody is having dinner tonight. Keep winding, keep winding. He's still there. Or did he get bit off? Guess what, you just got sharked.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You think so?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: How do you know for sure that was a shark, though?

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Feel that. That's sharp teeth, grabbed the fish and pulls it. Now could you imagine if you spent $3,000 to go fishing to catch that fish for dinner and it just got eaten?SANCHEZ (voice-over): Aiming to curb declining numbers, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration began implementing protections on sharks in the early 1990s. Shark. Shark right there. Look it right there.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes. Here it comes.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Tighter regulations mean more sharks. And according to Navarro, more sharks mean more encounters.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: There's a shark that just ate it. He just ate it. See him? Right there he just ate your bait. Your fish.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: That's three today that we've caught.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Or that we've got up but the sharks are them right next to the boat.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: It's a lot of work.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: It's a lot of work only to, what, lose it right at the end. It's tough.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You come home empty handed.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: You come home empty handed.The question is, are they trying to rebuild the stocks back to 100 percent or they trying to rebuild them back to a manageable level? And that's a question that I asked the agency this week. Going forward -- SANCHEZ (voice-over): Navarro is a member of NOAA's advisory panel for highly migratory species like sharks.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Right now depredation is a very big problem.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Other frustrated fishermen joined him in D.C. this May to voice their concerns.

utterances.speaker: ZALES
utterances.sentences: I've got videos on my phone that were sent to me from southeast Florida of sharks tearing the selfish up that they're trying to catch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There he is. And shark is standing, the shark just eating right there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Look at the shark eating, damn it.

utterances.speaker: ZALES
utterances.sentences: Sharks are just frankly a nuance for pretty much anybody fishing anywhere from Maine through Texas.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Why is that?

utterances.speaker: ZALES
utterances.sentences: Because the abundance of them.

utterances.speaker: CATHERINE MACDONALD, SHARK CONSERVATIONIST
utterances.sentences: So we're going to check this every 10 lines.SANCHEZ (voice-over): But some scientists disagree. Catherine Macdonald, who runs the Shark Research and Conservation Program at the University of Miami --

utterances.speaker: MACDONALD
utterances.sentences: So we're going to take a look.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: -- argues depredation may be due to overfishing.

utterances.speaker: MACDONALD
utterances.sentences: For the most part, fisheries independent monitoring data does not show a huge population increase. We may be depleting prey sources so that that increased competition has more to do with fewer fish to go around than it has to do with more sharks. There's a lot of scientists actually working on this topic right now. The question isn't, are those conflicts going to occur? Because we know that they are. It's how do we want to manage them and what do we want the future to look like.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So what was it that got you into marine life?NOAA officials say the problem is complex without an easy remedy. BREWSTER-GEISZ: We have been really successful in NOAA Fisheries at rebuilding some of these stocks. But there are a lot more recreational anglers now. That means there's a lot more fish being discarded or the fishermen are practicing catch and release. All of that is going to train sharks.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Is there any science-backed data that proves that depredation is a problem?BREWSTER-GEISZ: One of the things NOAA Fisheries is trying to do right now is fund a lot of research looking into depredation. But the solution is not going to be cull all sharks. All sharks are bad and you get rid of them.

utterances.speaker: NAVARRO
utterances.sentences: Look at him go. Look, he's getting chased. The shark got him.BREWSTER-GEISZ: Our solution is going to be something to minimize the interactions between sharks and the fishermen. And so first we have to collect the data. SANCHEZ (voice-over): Collecting that data involves serving populations or stock assessments, which fisherman like Fly thinks needs to happen as soon as possible. BREWSTER-GEISZ: I would agree with him.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So then what's the challenge in getting it done? Because he feels like the federal government isn't listening to fishermen like him.BREWSTER-GEISZ: We try very hard. There is a whole process. We work within NOAA. We work with other groups to determine which species, not just sharks, should be assessed when. It takes time to do the assessments. SANCHEZ (voice-over): When we return scientists inspiring the next generation of researchers.

utterances.speaker: MACDONALD
utterances.sentences: It's to give them that firsthand experience, their own story that they will carry with them.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: As the future for sharks appears murky.If we keep killing 100 million sharks a year where would that leave us? (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [20:53:43] MACDONALD: We are in Biscayne Bay just a couple of miles from downtown Miami, Florida.

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: And we are out fishing for sharks and hopes of catching and tagging them.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Scientists Catherine MacDonald and Jillian Morris are giving young girls a real-life lesson on apex predators.

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: Then you're going to push, push, push, and feel hard. Yes. Good job. Now spin it. Perfect. That's it.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Teaching them how to tag sharks for research.

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: When the horn blows, you're going to drop the fish in and then we're going to let that coil out, OK?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Morris founded the non-profit organization Sharks for Kids.

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: You need science for conservation, but you also need education. And so if kids grow up understanding how valuable sharks are for healthy oceans, they're going to do better than our generations have done in taking care of this incredible habitat.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: She is partnering with Macdonald who runs the Shark Research and Conservation Program at the University of Miami.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 95 PCM. 9-5. Let go.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Awesome.

utterances.speaker: MACDONALD
utterances.sentences: Nice.(CHEERS)

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: Think about when you go to the doctor, right? And you get a physical or checkup, it's really the same kind of thing that they're doing.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And this is a clipping, a small clipping of the fin? MORRISyour fingernails or cutting your hair. It's not hurting the animal out, feeling it, if you're doing that right, it shouldn't be feeling it. And it's giving us DNA. You can do a shark family tree, essentially.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So what's happening now?

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: So now we have a student who is hoisting a tag in.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: And what is the tag keeping track of?

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: They're looking at how many sharks we're catching, which species, and then that tag number is linked to all the other data.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: How does this help protect sharks?

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: So you have to have baseline data. You have to have an understanding when people make statements like populations are going up or down. Or you hear people say, oh, there's too many sharks. You don't know that unless you have data.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So you just tagged a shark. What was that like?

utterances.speaker: PAULA MORA, FOURTH GRADER
utterances.sentences: Like it felt pretty weird. It's was really cool.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes? You like sharks?

utterances.speaker: MORA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: What was going through your mind as you were looking at it?

utterances.speaker: MORA
utterances.sentences: I was like, oh, my god. I can't believe I just tagged a shark.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Collecting one key data point from the seven sharks they tagged is especially critical given that these waters are actually a nursery. And this is a sonogram that's taking place right now.

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: This is really exciting.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we have babies.(CHEERS)

utterances.speaker: MACDONALD
utterances.sentences: So if a little shark can make it here, they can make it in other places where they need to co-exist with people. And that gives us a lot of hope for the future of shark conservation.SANCHEZ (voice-over): Hope that globally seems to be in short supply.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: And the odds are stacked against the sharks. For every human that gets killed at least 10 million sharks get killed.

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: Well, now overfished. The scary part is they're being fished sometimes before they can even reproduce.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: If we keep killing 100 million sharks a year, where would that leave us?

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure where it would leave us. Where it would leave sharks is with a lot of species going extinct. One in three shark species minimum right now is threatened to go extinct in the near future because of overfishing. Those species will never come back. They will never contribute to a healthy marine ecosystem again. I'm really worried that it would put ecosystems out of whack in a way we don't completely understand.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He just took it out of my hand.

utterances.speaker: HAMMERSCHLAG
utterances.sentences: Shark depredation is an issue and I think it's an issue that needs to be addressed. But I don't think culling sharks is the way to address that. I think there needs to be more science behind what are the factors that might increase depredation rates? Because if we can understand what goes into that, then maybe we can modify the way we fish in a way that could reduce that.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: We see sharks slowly recovering in some places that protect them. U.S. is one example. So we got good fishes management, some sharks are recovering. At the same time other species might not recover because we're still fishing them.BREWSTER-GEISZ: We definitely have some shark species that are in need of conservation. We also have some species that are really healthy and that can withstand a lot more fishing pressure than we allow on them.

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: The good news is that overfishing is the main threat to sharks by far. And overfishing can be addressed by changing human behavior. We can regulate the numbers of sharks that are allowed to be landed. We can regulate the fishing gears that are to be used and we can have wider regulations on, say, which species are allowed to be traded over international boundaries.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: How important is it to change the perception that people have of sharks?

utterances.speaker: WORM
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it starts with seeing sharks for what they are and not what were made to believe they are. And seeing them as a vital and critical part of ocean ecosystem, something we cannot afford to lose. We can reduce overfishing. We've done it in the past. We've done it for other species. We've saved whales. We're saving turtles. We can save sharks.SANCHEZ (voice-over): A challenge that will define the health of our oceans for generations.

utterances.speaker: MORRIS
utterances.sentences: We have taken hundreds of kids out in the field to tag sharks. It's to give them that firsthand experience, their own story that they will carry with them. It's not what they read in a book. It's not what they saw on TV. It's not what somebody told them. Like be afraid of sharks. It's they have their own connection and their own story, and that stays with them. They are wild animals, but they're not monsters and they're in big trouble.And if we don't have these conversations and we don't support research and conservation, they're disappearing and they're going to keep disappearing. So the time is now to take action to save these animals. (END VIDEOTAPE)
